content_scrubbed:
Honestly, the institutions of the Canadian state are taught very poorly in Highschool civics - they're taught, but in a half semester and the curriculum must also cover fed/prov/municipal balances, elections and electoral math, political parties and partizan politics, role of the media, etc. all in a way that[.] testable so that 15/16 year-olds will mostly pass *(note: what was most important at that age? for me it was literally the girl I was just starting to date who I sat beside.* **nothing** *was distracting me from that particular redhead)*

It[.] just not really taught in the public school curriculum beyond that (because the other half of that semester is Careers, and that shit[.] important too) and the next place anyone might encounter formal education on the institutions of the Canadian state is in a full-year intro PoliSci course in an Undergrad. That[.] IF you're not a science/engineering/math/nursing/[*insert other specialized programs here*] student, and have the free credits/units. Note that the programs *most* suited to taking this stuff are in SocSci/Humanities, and the job market there is rough. It[.] just not reasonable to expect everyone to make the choices that provide an opportunity to take that course.

It[.] definitely a curriculum failure, but, man, think of all the shit we gotta teach inattentive kids. The solution, in my mind, is full-year education. Good luck with that, though.
